Fields.DialogueText: What are you reading there, Delhi? More of the Mahābhārata?
Yes. It is so compelling and complex that I keep going back to it again and again.
Yeah, good books are like that. I forgot to ask the last time, but what is it about?
Many different things, but mostly a long feud and eventual war between two branches of an especially large family.
It must have been an epic struggle, given the size of that book.
It was. By the end, only a few of the heroes on both sides were alive.
Heroes on both sides? So it wasn't just a battle between good and evil?
No, wars are rarely like that. True, the one branch was just a little more than the other, but they both had their reasons.
And yet the family still killed each other off.
It's sad, but it can happen. With too many people connected to each other, you start to neglect some of the bonds in favor of others. And eventually, you no longer grasp each other.
That's an interesting way to looking at things.
The dynamic isn't uncommon. A big family is nice, but... sometimes those same ties can lead to strife rather than affection.
Is that why you tend to be a loner?
Partially. I like having people that I'm friends with, but I want them to really count. If even family can grow apart... well. You see my dilemma.

Fields.MenuText: We never know fully what might happen. Better to regret than never having had the chance to know for sure.
That just means we have to put more effort into all of the bonds we have, so nobody feels left out.
And yet you are still reaching out. That's very brave of you.

Fields.DialogueText: I know. Only the powers above know the truth of what is to come. For better or worse, I will try to open my heart to the world and its wonders and sorrows.
You're right. But friendships have to be mutual to work out in the end. You have to trust that the person you put your faith in wants to believe in you as well.
I'm a proud Indian warrior and British sailor. Nothing sets me back, even the things that I worry about.
Say, do you think you could lend your book to me sometime?
Sure. Or otherwise, I could read it aloud to you. That is the original form of the narrative, after all.
Whichever way you like. Right now, though, we have our own war to worry about.
Yes, indeed. Even with dozens of gods and spirits and heroes involved in that struggle, they have nothing on this one!
@BATTLE
Oh, hey there, Captain. You look like you're in a hurry.
Did you see a monkey go through here? The mangy thing stole my hat!
Don't worry. I think it looks very nice on him.
"Him"? You know this monkey?
Why, yes. I snuck him on board just the other day.
Delhi, why? We have enough trouble without a simian running around loose.
The poor thing was being smuggled to be somebody's pet or dinner. I just couldn't let them do that.
But you just had to bring it on board.
It was so sweet and followed me right onto the ship!
Delhi, if it keeps wreaking havoc, we'll have to do something about it. I've already got some crew fishing around for a zookeeper's net and tranquilizers.
Don't hurt it! Monkeys are sacred in India. Why, their god Hanuman is renowned as a patron of heroes and storytellers alike.

Fields.MenuText: I can see why you like him, then. Sounds like that deity's a lot like you.
Delhi, it's for his own good that we move him off the ship. This isn't a place where he'll be happy.
Just make sure you take good care of it. Friends look out for each other.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, I admire that sense of duality and try to apply it to my own life.
I was thinking he might like the gardens. But you're probably right.
Yes. That's part of why I brought him here. I thought this could help me practice how to interact with others.
Well, I guess there's not much we can do now that it's here. Until we find a zoo that can take it in, we might as well make our guest feel at home.
Thank you, Captain.
Just as long as I get my hat back.
Don't worry. He gave it to me.
Great! But you'd better keep it out of the way for now. We don't want any monkey business in our fights.
@BATTLE
Well, I'm not sure it will work. Then again, Belles aren't exactly human either.
All right, Captain. Ready for our next bout.
As ready as I'll ever be. You've won every match so far.
Don't worry, we're just getting started with the training.
That's exactly what worries me. But let's do this. Take that!
You're getting better, but your guard is still off– whoa! You almost got me there.
Like you said, I'm learning every time.
I see... You purposefully left your flank open so I would focus on it. That is quite the bold move.
Heh. I got the idea from you.
Perhaps I should take fewer risks if it sets a bad example. Still, that was innovative thinking there. You're really coming along well.
Thanks! I want to do my best, after all.
Still, I don't want you to get hurt in battle. You can leave the burden to me.

Fields.MenuText: Isn't that a double standard?
Delhi, the reason I came to you is so I can help my friends out, including you.
We're at risk every day in this war. I promise not to be too reckless, but if it makes a difference, I'll put every card on the table.

Fields.DialogueText: It is. I guess we both care too much.
Thank you. That means a lot to me. Let's try to do our best as a team, then.
As will I. You are maturing into a great hero.
So, do I finally win a match?
Not quite!
Hey! I thought we were done!
A soldier should be prepared for anything.
Including Morganas, by the looks of it.
@BATTLE
I will fight, to the end...
Hey, how's it going?
Wah! Don't startle me like that!
Sorry. Sounds like an interesting play. Is this one from an Indian war of long ago?
Yes, but not that long ago. This is from the siege of Calcutta by the British.
I see. It sounds like an interesting play.
Yes. I got interested in plays after Tasmania, and this one stood out to me.
Maybe we can perform it sometime. I can go asking around–
No, don't!
Why?
I don't want word to get out that I like this play. Especially to my sisters.
I don't see the problem. It's a British play, so why...oh. Are the British forces the antagonists?
Essentially, yes. The play is highly censored back home, so please keep this our little secret, all right?

Fields.MenuText: I thought that you were the one who said people need to understand each other to get along?
It's kind of lonely performing with no audience, though.
Nothing stays secret forever.

Fields.DialogueText: You think it's easy? I want to say something, but I'm afraid of what will happen if I don't get things out right.
I'm used to it. But might you stay a little longer to watch?
I know. I just need a little more time, like everything else in this war.
All right, your secret's safe with me. But you'll have to tell them eventually.
Yeah...
*ALARM*
We have other things to deal with first, though.
Let's make sure that this does not leave us stranded like Siraj at Calcutta.
@BATTLE
Delhi, are you in– aiyeeh!
Are you all right, Captain?
I'm fine. But ice, indoors?
I wanted to set up an ice hockey arena.
Well, try to be careful. It's easy to slip and shiver.
Here. These skates will help.
Thanks... why do you have a matching hockey outfit, though?
I thought that for the next step of our training, we could do a hockey match.
One-on-one?
For now, yes. I might like to start a team later, though. So let's get started.

Fields.MenuText: I'm surprised you like a sport so cold.
Isn't hockey kind of rough?
Who's going to protect the goals?

Fields.DialogueText: I've traveled to many cool climates. Plus, this is good endurance training.
Of course it is. It is like a battle of brave warriors. Thus, a great exercise.
I admit that the sport works best with teams. But we can figure things out.
Fine.
Great! Though, on second thought, maybe we should wait.
What a relief!
Don't get too cocky! The reason I postponed is because the Morganas might melt the ice otherwise.
@BATTLE
Hmm... I see. Sigh...
What's the matter, Delhi?
I just got a message. There's a Soviet convoy passing through, so we'll be cooperating for a little while.
That's good. We can use all the help we can get against the Morganas.
I know, but be careful around them.
Why, you don't trust them?
My very first mission when I was built was to keep them out of the Baltic. And even then, they still seized a lot of territories that just wanted to be left alone.
It's been a while, so maybe things have changed.
Perhaps, but for better or for worse?

Fields.MenuText: Well, they're our allies out here, so try to be on your best behavior.
Kind of like India's own story, huh?
I would have thought you'd like communism, with its emphasis on everyone working together.

Fields.DialogueText: I know that. I am a soldier, so I will remain dignified... despite my internal disgust.
...Yes, in a way.
There are parts that I respect in their philosophy, but the Soviet approach irritates me. Teamwork is not imposed from on high.
Well, let's get this over with.
I think I see them over there. And– oh! It looks like some Morganas have decided to join the party as well.
Come on, then. Whatever my issues with them, I won't let them fall prey to the Morganas out here.
You have a great heart, Delhi. Never let go of that.
@BATTLE
What are you reading now? Another Indian epic?
No. Treasure Island by Robert Louis Stevenson.
Oh? I didn't know that you were a fan of his.
He died in Samoa, where he was known as Tusitala. I visited his grave when I stopped at Apia. He was truly a man of the seas, like us.
So what do you think of his book?
... Well, it's not my favorite.
Why not?
It's not that I don't like the narrative. He's great with that. It's just that, after chasing those pirates outside of China, I've never had much taste for their ilk.

Fields.MenuText: Well, keep in mind that they're the villains of the story.
Don't let your past history keep you from enjoying the overall tone of things.
I thought you would like the themes.

Fields.DialogueText: Good point. It just unsettled me how they pretended to be friends before turning on them like that.
You're right. It's a great book otherwise.
I do. The theme of family fighting family – in a fashion, with the mentorship Long John gave Jim – brought me to tears, just like the Mahābhārata.
All right, it's not really that bad.
I never realized that Stevenson ended his career so far away at sea, on such a small island.
I guess he finally found people he could share a home with. Good friends are hard to come by.
But they're still the most valuable treasure of all, if you put enough effort into it.
That's right. I just have to try harder.
Give it your best shot, just like you do against these Morganas.
At least they're not as bad as buccaneers.
@BATTLE
Listening to the radio, I see.
Yes, but keep it down, please. The speech is about to start.
Who's the speaker? Churchill? Gandhi?
Actually, I'm listening to one of Roosevelt's talks.
That's interesting. I didn't know you liked him.
He's not one of the people I take orders from, but he's done a lot for our cause against the Axis. I know we can count on him for help against the Morganas.
I see. And you want to stay informed on things.
Exactly. It's best to stay aware about everything in the world. Plus, he has a way of giving people hope.
We can certainly use a helping of that.
Still, I wonder how long he'll hold on, with all this pressure?

Fields.MenuText: It's hard on all of us. We just have to keep faith that we can make the most of our time here, and that someone will pick up where we left off.
Even so, he's already overcome a lot of challenges since the beginning.
Let's focus on the things we can make a difference in.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, but it's sometimes hard. Still, I'm not giving up that easy.
You're right. It's his way of finding solutions to his problems that inspires me to try harder every day.
Yes, even if we can't help him or the people back home, we can still help each other out here and stop the Morganas.
Anyway, it's kind of surprising that you're a fan of him, given the old relationship between the U.S. and Mother England, after all.
That was a while ago. In any case, I'm happy that they're doing well and that we can get along on decently good terms.
Yeah. With the Morganas on the prowl, we need every ally we can to turn back the tide.
@BATTLE
I know you won't.
Mmm! What's cooking?
The latest catch of the day, and one that's interested since that time in Madeira: espada!
Sorry, no speak espada.
Very funny. It's also called the black scabbardfish.
Interesting. What's with the bananas? Are they for dessert?
Actually, I plan to mix them together. The two flavors blend very well.
Huh. I didn't know that.
Still, I want to give it my own unique touch to it. But what to do, what to do...?
Maybe I can help.
You can? Great! Do you have any ideas?

Fields.MenuText: How about espada sushi?
Scabbard chips?
Maybe you could make some kind of curry.

Fields.DialogueText: It has a nice ring to it, but it won't work. This species is notorious for hosting a dangerous parasite. Things should be fine as long as we cook it, but we can't risk eating it cold.
Not a bad idea. The crispiness combined with the softness of the banana would make for quite a treat.
That sounds good. I love spicy things.
Thanks for the help.
Hey, what are friends for?
Say, do you think you could watch the food for a little bit while I find the others?
Before, you'd ask for the opposite.
I'm trying something new. Just don't leave your station, please.
Don't worry, it's safe with me.
Great! Thanks again.
Well, it's just you and me, fish... and these Morganas. Delhi, now what do I do?!
@BATTLE
Nuts! These Morganas are swarming us like flies.
But they're also falling like flies just as quick– watch your flank there!
@BATTLE
You're holding out pretty well so far!
Same for all of us. I've got a plan with some of the other girls to turn this battle around.
Great! It's good to see we're all pitching in to win this fight.
Exactly. Our bonds are what give us the edge against the Morganas, though some new tech will also come in handy.
And maybe we can have a party once we win.
Maybe.

Fields.MenuText: Whatever you feel like.
Just keep up the good work, and don't give up on each other.
Remember, we are all brethren in this war, and our bond is eternal.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, what I feel like doing... I'll see.
Thanks! I won't let you down.
That's a bold statement, Captain. But I like it.
We've got them now!
Good, but don't let up. We don't want anything marring the party, do we?
So you are amenable to the idea after all.
Well, since everyone else seems happy...
Anyway, it's time to end this brawl. You with me, Delhi?
Yep! I've got you covered.
Heave, ho! Heave, ho! Up from the sea you go!
Delhi, what's with all of this salt laying on deck? Not to mention the water.
Ah, Captain, there you are. I am in the midst of extracting salt from seawater. It was a little tricky at first, but I think I've got it now.
I can see that. I didn't realize that we were low on salt, though. We picked up a bunch on our last shore leave...
That was salt we had to pay for. This salt we obtained on our own, without having to depend on anyone.
And that's important to you?
It is. When you can make something with your own power, you are no longer dependent on others. And a dependent relationship is toxic over time.
Is that part of why you try to be so distant?
...Yes. When you have to rely on someone, it not only weakens you, but it corrupts the partner, until you are servant and master.

Fields.MenuText: That's a valid argument, but the opposite end of the spectrum can be just as bad.
On the other hand, teamwork has its own benefits.
I think it's less about needing others, and more about finding a way for us to help each other out, as equals.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose you're right at that.
That's one thing, but... I'm just afraid of things shattering in the end.
Yes, as equals... perhaps that is the true path to take.
Anyway, do you mind if I lend you a hand?
Sure! The more the merrier.
Whew! This is hard work.
But satisfying, nonetheless.
We certainly won't have to worry about a salt shortage anytime soon.
Say, I wonder what those Morganas would be like served with salt on top?
Let's just beat them before we spill any.
@BATTLE
My head... now what do I do?
I see you're writing now, not reading.
They're both enjoyable pastimes.
Well, whatever makes you happy. What are you writing about, by the way? More notes about the Morganas?
Yes. I'm trying to make it into a comprehensive study that people can use to learn from.
That sounds great. I know you'll do a good job with it.
Thanks, but for some reason I keep getting stuck.
How come?
I don't know, that's the problem. I just can't find the motivation for it.
Maybe I can help.

Fields.MenuText: Why don't you get some fresh air and exercise for the moment?
I think the problem is that the kind of literature you like the most is epic narrative, not dry recitation.
How about you skip ahead to a different section? Since it's a guide, you can jump between the different parts more easily than a straightforward story.

Fields.DialogueText: That's probably for the best. I won't get anywhere at this rate, so I may as well free up my mind.
You may have a point there. This is supposed to be a realistic documentary, but I could make the text a little more engaging.
Sure, why not? I can fill in the gaps as I gather more info during battles.
Thanks. I think I am on the right track now.
My pleasure. Can I have a copy when you're finished?
Yep. You and everyone in the fleet. We can all use our knowledge to grow stronger.
That's good. Especially since the Morganas haven't been taking it easy either.
@BATTLE
Everyone, get to your stations!
@BATTLE
There! That should take care of them. Good work, everyone!
Thank you, Captain. But I think you missed one important detail.
What? Are there more coming back?
No, no. I am referring to your sleeve.
My sleeve? Oh, it's just a minor rip.
Still, those aberrant strands could snag you at an untimely moment. I insist that I fix it up for you.
That's very nice of you.
Well, I thought that I may as well use my knowledge to assist my sisters and crew with their own clothes, even if they don't always recognize the need.
We aren't all as particular as you, Delhi.
And I lack your blissful ignorance of elegant attire, but we cannot have all we want. So, shall I start the repairs?

Fields.MenuText: Say "please" first.
Sure. I really appreciate it.
If you let me watch. I'm interested in learning how to do it myself.

Fields.DialogueText: All right. May I please tidy you up?
Hey, what are friends for?
Now that you mention it, that might be a better long-term solution for all of us. Good idea!
All right, here's the sleeve.
On second thought, put it back on.
Huh? Why?
You'll probably get messier during the party. Now come on. We don't want to miss the festivities!
All right, all right, I'm coming.
Go ahead.
All right, Delhi, I'm ready for our next training session.
Actually, we might end up postponing it.
Why? I was looking forward to it – all right, not the getting beat up, but it's still fun practicing with you.
It's just... I've been thinking, and I want to take things to the next level, for all of us.
What do you mean?
These bouts have helped me move forward in socializing, but I want to do more. So I think I am going to start a training class for the full fleet.
That sounds like a bold move. But if you're up for it, I'm right behind you all the way.
Right beside me, actually. I want you to be a fellow instructor with me.
Really? This... I don't know what to say. I thought I still had a ways to go.
We all do. But you have become very strong, and I have faith you can carry part of the load, as we are now equals.

Fields.MenuText: Just as long as we can still challenge each other in duels now and then.
I look forward to the additional responsibility. I hope that I can make you proud, teacher.
That sounds like fun.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course. We can always help each other grow stronger that way.
I know you will.
It will be. I'm still a little nervous, but I'm actually looking forward to the new challenge.
I guess the next step is to plan out the course, right?
Yes, after we fight!
Hey! I thought you said we were postponing!
Never let your guard down, Captain! And I need to make sure you have the guts for the position.
All right, I'll show you what I can really do. After we handle these Morganas, that is.
@BATTLE
Captain, we need to hurry, a fleet of Morganas is about to strike!
@BATTLE
We beat them good, huh?
What? Oh. Yeah, we did.
Something bothering you?
No. I was just about to make a small prayer.
For the fallen? You're not the only one.
Yes, but I mean all of them. Including other sides.
You're praying for the Morganas we just sunk?
Yes, and an apology for hurting them.
You don't have to apologize for that. We didn't have any choice in the matter if we wanted to live on.
I know, but killing is still a sin. True, this war is necessary, but we must not forget the price we pay.
What do you mean?
There was a great king called Ashoka who established a mighty empire and beat down all his enemies. Yet, at the end, he felt an emptiness inside him, and regret.
What happened to him?
He found salvation through the teachings of the Buddha. But anyway, I just feel that we should respect all life. Sometimes we don't get a choice, but we must still know the wrong.

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps one day we can understand their feelings and help them find new light.
Not everything is left up to fate, though. We can still make some choices.
You are a complex woman, Delhi, a symbol of both war and peace.

Fields.DialogueText: That is my dream. Not only for the Morganas, but for everyone caught up in these endless wars.
And let us pray that we make the best choices we can when the time comes.
Such is the duality of life and death, sorrow and joy. Beautiful in a way, is it not?
Well, I'm done. Now that we have mourned the departed, we can celebrate the living.
Exactly. I think the party's already started.
Then let's get a move on.
Sigh...
What's wrong, Delhi?
I was just listening to the radio. Newcastle upon Tyne – part of Elswick – has been bombed again.
That's terrible! Is everyone all right?
We're hanging in there. Most of the monuments and industrial works are still intact. Not that things were so bright before anyway...
What do you mean by that?
Well, the living conditions in Elswick aren't the best. Though they're at least better than the streets of Delhi.
Lots of poverty, I take it?
Yes, and I have a feeling that it will get worse before it improves.
Think we can do something about it?
Help a little, I guess, but I'm not sure how. The decisions are up to the governments, and I don't want to make people indebted to me.

Fields.MenuText: The ultimate choices are up to others, but we can at least get them started on the first steps.
We can set an example for others to follow.
Perhaps our efforts won't make much of a difference in the end, but we can still do something.

Fields.DialogueText: Good point. It takes one person to start things rolling, after all.
You're right. Together, we can all act as beacons of hope for the poor, and a path for others to follow.
Yes, there is no point worrying about what may be. The future is ever changing, so we should just focus on doing the right thing.
Maybe we can start some lessons about the subject.
Yeah, though we have to worry about the war first, or things will get worse regardless.
I know. Fortunately, with the luck we have at finding Morganas, the war will be over in no time.
@BATTLE
Trying to paint some art?
Yes. I was thinking that we could really use an art gallery on board.
That sounds like fun. Although most of the paintings look pretty similar. And why wine? You don't even like it.
I wanted to do a tribute to Alexander Laing, who founded an art gallery in Newcastle few decades back.
He was a wine connoisseur, I take it.
Exactly. The Scottish variety, to be precise. Plus, it means I don't get thirsty even when I'm painting them.

Fields.MenuText: Variety is good too, though.
Just paint what you feel like. It'll all be beautiful.
Some of the others might want to feature their own art as well.

Fields.DialogueText: You have a point there. Wines are said to have variety, but that comes from actually tasting them.
Thanks. I've had fun so far, but I think I'm going to switch things out soon.
That would be awesome. I'll see if anyone is interested.
Well, that's enough for now. I want to change things up, but I'm not sure what to paint next.
Don't worry. I'm sure inspiration will come to you.
It certainly did. Here they come now!
And they're really rocking the boat this time.
Oh, no! The alcohol is all over me now.
You can clean yourself up afterward. We have some enemies to break first.
@BATTLE
What'cha up to, Delhi?
Just fixing a few of the lights. They come in handy when the sun goes down.
That's nice of you. Are things going all right, though?
Don't worry, I have a knack for this. Part of the old Tyne tradition.
That's good to hear. Just be careful not to blow a fuse.
I'll try not to do that. Say, could you please hand me those pliers over there?
What? Sure. Glad to help.
Thanks. You know, it's interesting how we have always been so fascinated with making our own light. Not content with the cycles of the sun and moon, we made our own fires.
Do you think that's wrong?
Not exactly. It is great that we challenge ourselves to peer past our natural limits. Still, sometimes the darkness deserves love as well, don't you think?

Fields.MenuText: I guess that neither end is good or bad when you really look at them.
We do have a tendency to surround ourselves with lights, don't we? It's useful, but you have a point. It can be a little too much at times.
And yet you are still fixing the lights in here.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly. Everything has its part to play in this world, and we need to embrace all of it to find peace in life.
That's my worry, especially as we continue to industrialize. Nature's untamed spaces have their own value as well.
I said I had issues with lights, but they're not all bad. Without them, the Morganas would have got us good way back.
There! The lights should be better than ever.
You're right. Even with the clouds covering things, I can see even farther than usu... uh, oh.
What's wrong?
We have Morganas approaching. Get into gear.
Don't worry. Pretty soon, it will be lights out for them.
@BATTLE
Huh, what's brewing? Some sort of tea?
Actually, no, though I might make a batch later. This is maté.
"Matte" as in Japanese? You want me to wait?
Well, I do want you to wait, but no, this is an Argentine beverage. Learned about it during my tour down there.
Cool. It looks a little like coffee.
That's not surprising. Caffeine is one of the key ingredients.
Well, that's definitely going to wake you up when you take a sip.
The flavor is excellent, though. I almost like it as much as I do tea.
Why don't you try mixing the two?
Now that you mention, there are tea variants for maté. But the process is tricky, so I've never tried it.

Fields.MenuText: The first try is always the hardest, but it gets better from there.
I can help you with it, if you want.
We won't know until we try.

Fields.DialogueText: That's exactly right. I'll see what I can do.
Sure. Two heads are better than one.
Good point. It's best to be adventurous if you want to enjoy new things.
There! It's done.
See? It wasn't that hard.
Thanks for lending a hand with it.
No problem. Want to pour a couple glasses?
Yep. Here we go!
Wait... that's a gourd.
It's the traditional way of drinking it.
Very well. This will get us psyched up for the battle on the horizon. Cheers!
@BATTLE
Practicing your archery, I see. Though it won't be of much use in battle.
You never know. Besides, I practice the art largely for the spiritual oneness it offers.
What do you mean?
You become one with the target, feeling their pain and joy as you target them. Such was the way of Arjuna in the Mahābhārata.
Like when he killed his kin?
Yes, exactly like that. He was very afraid, before the big battle, you know.
He was? Makes him pretty human, then. I feel the same way. So what happened?
A god mentored him and gave him the courage to go forward.
It must have been pretty hard, though.
It always is. We live in a world where honor and dishonor often mix, and where death is necessary for life to prosper. The key is to accept the world and move forward.

Fields.MenuText: That's easier said than done.
The world is very complicated, isn't it?
How do we apply that philosophy to the Morganas? Not to mention the other conflicts.

Fields.DialogueText: As it is to be expected. But the important thing is to try.
I know. But that is what makes life so glorious.
I'm still figuring that out. We all are. Things will work out, though. I know it will.
After all these millennia, we're still trying to find a cure to war, aren't we?
Hatred is an eternal curse. Even so, we can make the world a better place.
We certainly can. Let's do our best to end this war, one way or another.
Yep! Look out, Morganas, here we come!
@BATTLE
Captain? I wanted to get your permission for something.
What's that?
Well, I was thinking that we could host a special party?
What would make it so special? We have plenty of celebrations after our victories.
Yes, but this one is more of a cultural exchange combined with a proper meal.
I get it. You want the food and beverages to represent the different origins of the crew and ships.
Yes, all of them. I have some ones I plan to submit from both England and Delhi, for example.
That sounds great. I can get the word out if you want.
Thank you, but I'd like to handle this myself. I just wanted to make sure you knew.
You sure? You're usually kind of shy about doing that.
I was, but we're all friends now. That's part of why I want to hold this feast: to celebrate our friendship.

Fields.MenuText: You really like sharing different ideas with others, don't you?
Mind if I still lend you a hand? I want to help, too.
I admire your bravery in this, Delhi. Even more than your courage in battle.

Fields.DialogueText: It's in my blood. Delhi's always been a hub for multiple cultures, and I've had the opportunity to travel all around the world.
Of course. I appreciate the assistance, even if I'm able to stand on my own feet now.
Yes, it is easier to give in to rage and fight than have the strength to explore the truth of your heart. Fortunately, I've never been one to surrender.
Well, I need to compile a list of who all can bring food to the party.
We'll also need to time it right so we don't get interrupted. Like now!
If only the Morganas could learn from us as well.
@BATTLE
Delhi, could we slow down, please?
Come on, the pace isn't that bad. Besides, you don't want the others to see their captain underperform, do you?
All right, I'm not beat yet. Still, we've been running around for a while now. Is this really going to help us against the Morganas?
It sure will! I've been thinking we could learn some things from the Marathas and their tactics.
What sort of style did they use?
They were expert cavalrymen and warriors who used lightning raids to catch their opponents off guard.
And you think it will work against the Morganas?
They've caught us flatfooted too many times for my liking. We'll see how they like it when the same happens to them.

Fields.MenuText: We'll need to adjust things to make it work in a naval format, though.
The issue is finding the enemy in time and avoiding an ambush.
That would be a fitting twist after all these ambush raids.

Fields.DialogueText: I know that. But I think we can figure things out. Besides, we're getting good exercise.
Not to worry. Leave it to this old hunter.
My thoughts exactly. They've taught us the danger of ambushes, so now we can use that tactic against them.
Well, I think we can take a rest for the moment.
Phew! Good, now we can finally relax...
*ALARM*
Hey, at least we're all together at the moment.
And winded from the workout. But we'll have to make the best of it.
We'll get through it, no worries. Let's see if we can experiment with some new tactics this round.
@BATTLE
You're right. I can leave that in your reliable hands.
Up you go, into the– oof! I'm sorry, Captain! Are you all right?
I'm fine. What was the clamor about?
I was just trying to fly a kite.
Oh? Interesting. Is this an Indian variant?
Yes, straight from Delhi. I thought I might try to get it into the air.
You'll have plenty of opportunity today. The wind's been at it for hours.
I just ran into some trouble, though. It's difficult to run around long enough to get the kite into the air.
I can see that. Especially as you need to focus on the kite.
Exactly. I don't want it to get tangled up on something.
Hey, what if you tied it to the stern and sped up for a bit?
That... could work. But it's kind of unorthodox. Are you fine with it?

Fields.MenuText: What can I say? Being friends with you has given me a more open mind to new ideas.
You were saying we should practice speed tactics. Think of this as a way to kill two birds with one stone.
You can keep running around the deck if you like, but I feel that this would work out better.

Fields.DialogueText: Glad to hear it. Helping share my dream with others is one of my greatest joys.
That's right! I forgot about that. This would work perfectly.
I know. I just wanted to make sure you were fine with it first.
Well then, there's no time to waste. Here I go!
Whoa! You sure know how to move when you want to.
How's the kite doing? I'm focusing on the bow end of things right now.
It's doing good so far... it's in the air! All right, you can slow down now.
Not yet. There's a pack of Morganas dead ahead, so I'm charging into the fray.
Hopefully the kite can survive this oncoming storm.
@BATTLE
Don't worry. I believe in you.
Everything seems peaceful today. Maybe we won't run into any Morganas.
*ALARM*
Captain! There's an emergency!
What's wrong?
We sprung a leak!
Oh, no. Let's get it patched up quick before–
And the books!
Books?
Yes, the library is in danger!
That's what's worried you? What about the leak?
I'll hang in there. But I need to get the books to safety first.

Fields.MenuText: You matter more, Delhi. Focus on fixing yourself up first.
I'll have some of the crew tend to the books while you look after yourself. We're all working together, remember?
Do what you can to save the books, but don't neglect your own health too much.

Fields.DialogueText: I... understand. You're right. I need to be able to protect myself and everyone on board.
Good point. If we combine our efforts, we can deal with both problems at once.
Thanks. I'll keep that in mind.
All right, the books are safe. It wasn't as bad as I thought, and the leak's been repaired. Still, we need to get this battle done with before more issues come up.
You're right. Let's push forward! We can't back down now!
@BATTLE
So how are the plans coming along for the feast, Delhi?
Pretty well, actually. It's the other thing that's the tricky part.
What other thing?
You know how a lot of us have mixed origins?
Well, yeah. What's your point?
With all of us out here, we should be able to discuss our origins and work together to bring peace. But it hasn't happened yet.
And you think you have the answer.
It's rather simple, in all its complexity - we're all afraid of addressing those issues, especially to others. I was the same, until you helped me.
Delhi...
I want this feast to also be a meeting, in which we can all share our dreams and offer our aid to each other. Do you think it will work?

Fields.MenuText: As long as we make sure no one has their mouth too full of food when we're talking.
You have a wonderful vision for the world, Delhi. It's amazing how you bring everyone's hopes together. I want to be a part of it as well.
It will be tricky. Fortunately I'll be there to help.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, always a sense of humor with you. But anyway, I'm sure we can balance the dinner with the other matters.
Thanks, Captain. Actually, without you encouraging me, I might never have made it to this stage.
My thoughts exactly. If we present a united front, we can help the others open up as well.
Thanks for helping me with this.
Hey, this was ultimately your dream, one you acted on. Don't sell yourself short.
That's just who I am - someone who loves embracing the world's secrets, no matter how challenging it is for me.
If only the Morganas could learn from your ideals.
They'll figure it out someday. Just as we'll learn to communicate with them. Until then, we fight to the last breath.
